title: California Endures More Blackouts With Generators and Grit
text:
State officials and regulators have insisted that the situation cannot become the new normal. But for many Californians, it is beginning to feel familiar: huddling in the dark because of pre-emptive power shut-offs, or getting ready to do so.

Hundreds of thousands of customers of California’s three investor-owned utilities — Pacific Gas & Electric, Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas & Electric — endured blackouts on Thursday as the companies sought to prevent their equipment from igniting wildfires.

As PG&E prepared to inspect lines and restore power to 179,000 customers, mostly in Northern California, whose electricity had been shut off, Edison was beginning pre-emptive blackouts at the other end of the state that it said could affect almost 400,000 rate payers. The actual number of people losing power is generally much higher because each residential customer represents a household.

And with high winds blowing through much of the state, the fire threat was far from hypothetical. More than 10,000 acres were ablaze in Sonoma County from a fire of undetermined origin, forcing an evacuation of Geyserville, a town of 1,000 residents 75 miles north of San Francisco.
description: With wildfire hazards high and one major blaze reported, utility companies continued to shut off power to keep their equipment from causing a disaster.
